message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound in late diastole that precedes S1 is known as the S4 heart sound and is caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle, indicating left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation can cause an S3 heart sound. Increased filling pressures and mitral regurgitation can cause a different type of heart sound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound that immediately precedes S1 is known as an S4 heart sound, which is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation can lead to an S3 sound, increased filling pressures can also lead to an S3 sound, and mitral regurgitation is associated with a systolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as the S4 heart sound, and it is most commonly associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. This condition can be caused by poorly controlled hypertension, which the patient has a history of. Ventricular dilation and increased filling pressures can also lead to S4 heart sounds, but left ventricular hypertrophy is the most commonly associated condition. Mitral regurgitation is associated with a different heart sound, the systolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as the S4 heart sound, which is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation may result in a third heart sound (S3), increased filling pressures may result in both S3 and S4 heart sounds, and mitral regurgitation may result in a systolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as an S4 sound, and it is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation may lead to an S3 sound, while increased filling pressures may cause both S3 and S4 sounds. Mitral regurgitation usually produces a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound heard in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as S4 and is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation would result in S3, increased filling pressures may result in both S3 and S4, and mitral regurgitation would result in a systolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The extra heart sound in late diastole immediately precedes S1, which is the sound of the mitral valve closing. This extra sound is most commonly associated with left ventricular hypertrophy, which can be caused by poorly controlled hypertension. Ventricular dilation and increased filling pressures may also contribute to left ventricular hypertrophy, but they are not the direct cause of the extra heart sound. Mitral regurgitation would cause a murmur, not an extra heart sound.

The extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as an S4 gallop and is most associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation can cause an S3 gallop, increased filling pressures can cause elevated jugular venous pressure, and mitral regurgitation can cause a systolic murmur.

The extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as an S4 heart sound, which is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. Ventricular dilation and increased filling pressures are associated with an S3 heart sound, while mitral regurgitation is associated with an S2 heart sound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An extra heart sound in late diastole that immediately precedes S1 is known as S4, which is caused by increased atrial and ventricular filling pressures due to impaired relaxation of the ventricle. This is most commonly associated with left ventricular hypertrophy.
